prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Factors considered by the Panel—Familiarity of judge with litigation

para.paratext: The Panel has always been interested in assigning transferred cases to a judge who has become familiar with the issues in the litigation. This familiarity may come from presiding over related criminal[1] or patent[2] litigation or from handling the cases pending in the transferee district that are related to those to be transferred.[3] In one case the Panel observed:

We think that the just and efficient conduct of these actions will be best furthered by their transfer to a district wherein the assigned judge is already familiar with the proceedings and will be able to insure that consolidated pretrial proceedings are conducted fairly and expeditiously.[4]

The Panel may consider the experience gained in handling cases that have been settled or dismissed, and will therefore not be part of the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings upon transfer.[5] The Panel may be inclined to transfer cases to a transferee judge who is currently presiding over cases with which the Panel believes the transferred cases should be coordinated or consolidated.[6] These factors are significant in the selection of the transferee district as well as the question of selecting a transferee judge.[7] The Panel has even considered, in this vein, the pendency of cases in the transferee district that are similar in theory, although unrelated in factual issues and parties.[8] The Panel can consider simply the judge's “experience,” without being more specific.[9]

The mere fact that a particular judge has some familiarity with the proceedings does not, in itself, dictate assignment of the cases to that judge. The Panel has transferred cases to the same district as a related criminal case but not to the judge presiding over the criminal case.[10] This result may be reached even if coordination of the civil and criminal cases is one of the reasons for selecting the particular transferee district.[11] In one case the Panel noted that possible questions relating to self-incrimination of the criminal defendant made selection of a different judge in the same district “the wiser course.”[12] Similarly, the Panel has regularly transferred cases involving a party in bankruptcy or reorganization to the district where the bankruptcy or reorganization proceedings are pending.[13] In many cases, however, the Panel has determined not to assign the transferred cases to the judge presiding over the bankruptcy or reorganization proceedings[14] The Panel has reached this decision where the bankruptcy or reorganization proceedings are unduly complex or when conflicts in the positions of various parties would arise.[15] The Panel has noted that there is a “potential conflict between the rehabilitative purpose of reorganization and Section 1407's goal of expeditious pre-trial proceedings.”[16]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Polyester Staple Antitrust Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2003); see also cases discussed in § 6:12.
In re Oxycontin Antitrust Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Neurontin Antitrust Litigation, 217 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2002).

See, e.g., In re Proton-Pump Inhibitor Products Liability Litigation (No. II), 261 F. Supp. 3d 1351 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2017) (judge effectively managing cases pending in transferee district); In re Lumber Liquidators Chinese-Manufactured Flooring Durability Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 232 F. Supp. 3d 1344 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016) (judge familiar with issues from presiding over similar MDL docket); In re Genentech Herceptin (trastuzumab) Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 178 F. Supp. 3d 1374 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016) (experience of one year with this litigation); In re Service Corp. Intern., 323 F. Supp. 2d 1377 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (familiarity with prior cases against defendant); In re Ephedra Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1373 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Oxycontin Antitrust Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1388 (J.P.M.L. 2004) (familiarity with related patent case); In re Visa/Mastercard Antitrust Litigation, 295 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (familiarity from handling related class action for seven years); In re Beef Industry Antitrust Litigation, 419 F. Supp. 720 (J.P.M.L. 1976).
See In re IBM, 302 F. Supp. 796, 800 (J.P.M.L. 1969).

See In re Enfamil Lipil Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 764 F. Supp. 2d 1356 (J.P.M.L. 2011) (judge handled action all the way through settlement); In re Morgan Stanley Co. Overtime Pay Litigation (II), 471 F. Supp. 2d 1353 (J.P.M.L. 2007) (earlier cases settled); In re Panty Hose Seaming Patent Litigation, 402 F. Supp. 1401, 1403 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

See, e.g., In re Visa/Mastercard Antitrust Litigation, 295 F. Supp. 2d 1379 (J.P.M.L. 2003) (6 years experience handling class action noted by Panel); In re International House of Pancakes Franchise Litigation, 331 F. Supp. 556 (J.P.M.L. 1971); In re Protection Devices and Equipment and Central Station Protection Service Antitrust Cases, 295 F. Supp. 39 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
See § 6:14 for a more detailed discussion of these issues in the context of the selection of a transferee district.
See In re Sta-Power Industries Securities and Antitrust Litigation, 372 F. Supp. 1398, 1399 (J.P.M.L. 1974).

See, e.g., In re FCA US LLC Monostable Electronic Gearshift Litigation, 214 F. Supp. 3d 1354 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Dollar General Corp. Motor Oil Marketing and Sales Practices Litigation, 190 F. Supp. 3d 1361 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Viagra (Sildenafil Citrate) Products Liability Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1377 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re Windsor Wood Clad Window Products Liability Litigation, 176 F. Supp. 3d 1372 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2016); In re National Football League's “Sunday Ticket” Antitrust Litigation, 148 F. Supp. 3d 1358 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re: Amtrak Train Derailment In Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, On May 12, 2015, 140 F. Supp. 3d 1347 (U.S.J.P.M.L. 2015); In re Zyprexa Products Liability Litigation, 314 F. Supp. 2d 1380 (J.P.M.L. 2004); In re Immunex Corp. Average Wholesale Price Litigation, 201 F. Supp. 2d 1378 (J.P.M.L. 2002).
See In re Refrigerant Gas Antitrust Litigation, 334 F. Supp. 996 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
See In re Polyester Staple Antitrust Litigation, 259 F. Supp. 2d 1376 (J.P.M.L. 2003); In re Refrigerant Gas Antitrust Litigation, 334 F. Supp. 996, 998 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
See In re Refrigerant Gas Antitrust Litigation, 334 F. Supp. 996, 998 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
The role of pending bankruptcy or reorganization proceedings on the question of transfer and of selection of a transferee district is discussed in § 6:12.

See, e.g., In re Multidistrict Litigation Involving Banking Agreements with Stirling Homex Corp., 388 F. Supp. 572, 573 (J.P.M.L. 1975); In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1021, 1023 (J.P.M.L. 1971).

See, e.g., In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 221 (J.P.M.L. 1971) (potential conflict); In re Penn Cent. Securities Litigation, 322 F. Supp. 1021, 1023 (J.P.M.L. 1971) (transferee judge already consumed in mammoth litigation).
See In re Four Seasons Securities Laws Litigation, 328 F. Supp. 221, 224 (J.P.M.L. 1971).
